responses: Coronaviruses are a large family of viruses which may cause illness in animals or humans.  In humans, several coronaviruses are known to cause respiratory infections ranging from the common cold to more severe diseases such as Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) and Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS). The most recently discovered coronavirus causes coronavirus disease COVID-19.

patterns: What are the symptoms of coronavirus

responses: Symptoms of coronavirus includes: Fever, Cough, Shortness of breath, Chills, Muscle pain, Headache, Sore throat, and loss of taste or smell.
Common symptoms include fever,  tiredness, and dry cough. Other people may experience aches and pains, nasal congestion, runny nose, sore throat, and diarrhoea

patterns: When do i seek medical attention
When do i go to the doctor
When do i get medical attention
When will i know that i should go to the doctor?
E-hub, when should i go to the doctor
When is the time when i should go to the doctor?
responses: If you develop emergency warning signs for COVID-19 get medical attention immediately. Emergency warning signs includes: Trouble breathing, Persistent pain or pressure in the chest, New confusion or inability to arouse, Bluish lips of face
If you think that you have the symptoms of the disease and have contact with other patients, seek help immediately.

patterns: Who is most vulnerable target with the covid-19
Who are at most risk to coronavirus
I have diabetes, am i more vulnerable to the the virus
Can i easily acquire the virus
Am I a target of covid-19
responses: Covid-19 can affect anyone. However, the most vulnerable are older persons, persons with underlying diseases like high-blood pressure, heart disease, lung disease cancer, and diabetes

COVID-19 is a new disease and there is limited information regarding risk factors for severe disease. Based on currently available information and clinical expertise, older adults and people of any age who have serious underlying medical conditions might be at higher risk for severe illness from COVID-19.

patterns: Where is the origin of covid19
responses: The disease was first identified in December 2019 in Wuhan, the capital of China's Hubei province, and has since spread globally, resulting in the ongoing 2019–20 coronavirus pandemic.The disease was first identified in December 2019 in Wuhan, the capital of China's Hubei province, and has since spread globally, resulting in the ongoing 2019–20 coronavirus pandemic.

A 55-year-old individual from Hubei province in China may have been the first person to have contracted COVID-19, the disease caused by the new coronavirus spreading across the globe. That case dates back to Nov. 17, 2019, according to the South Morning China Post.

patterns: How long is the incubation period of covid19
How long till i experience symptoms
How long till I get sick
Will I get sick as soon as i am infected
How long till the disease shows symptoms
When will the symptoms show up
How long till i know i have covid-19
How long until it shows symptoms
Period until I know i have virus
How long till i know i have virus
responses: The 'incubation period', means the time between catching the virus and beginning to have symptoms of the disease. Most estimates of the incubation period for COVID-19 range from 1-14 days, most commonly around five days.
The incubation period (time from exposure to the development of symptoms) of the virus is estimated to be between 2 and 14 days.

patterns: Can the virus live on air
Can I get infected through air
How long till the disease shows symptoms
Will i catch the virus from the air
responses: Until now, there is no evidence that the virus is airborne, The virus that causes COVID-19 is mainly transmitted through droplets generated when an infected person coughs, sneezes, or speaks. These droplets are too heavy to hang in the air. They quickly fall on floors or surfaces.

patterns: How can i prevent the spread of the virus
How do i prevent the spread of covid
How can we control the upsurge of the virus
How can i mitigate the prolification of the virus
How do i stop the spread of virus
How can i avoid being infected by the virus
How can we lessen the spread of the virus
responses: To prevent the spread of the virus, follow the following instructions: (1). Stay home if you are sick, except to get medical care. (2). Avoid public transportation, ride-sharing, or taxis. (3).  Maintain a safe distance from anyone who is coughing or sneezing, and lastly, don’t touch your face, eyes, nose, or mouth when your hands are dirty

patterns: How can the virus spread like that
responses: People can catch COVID-19 from others who have the virus. The disease can spread from person to person through small droplets from the nose or mouth which are spread when a person with COVID-19 coughs or exhales.
The virus can spread when the droplets released of someone who is infected  lands on your mouth or nose.

The virus that causes COVID-19 is thought to spread mainly from person to person, mainly through respiratory droplets produced when an infected person coughs or sneezes. These droplets can land in the mouths or noses of people who are nearby or possibly be inhaled into the lungs. Spread is more likely when people are in close contact with one another (within about 6 feet).

The coronavirus - known as COVID-19 - spreads from person to person in close proximity, similar to other respiratory illnesses, such as the flu. Droplets of bodily fluids - such as saliva or mucus - from an infected person are dispersed in the air or on surfaces by coughing or sneezing. These droplets can come into direct contact with other people or can infect those who pick them up by touching infected surfaces and then their face.

patterns: How long does the virus survive on surfaces
How long can covid survive on the surface
Can the virus survive on surfaces
How long can it survive on the surface
responses: It is not certain how long the virus that causes COVID-19 survives on surfaces, but it seems to behave like other coronaviruses. Studies suggest that coronaviruses (including preliminary information on the COVID-19 virus) may persist on surfaces for a few hours or up to several days. This may vary under different conditions (e.g. type of surface, temperature or humidity of the environment).
The coronavirus can live for hours to days on surfaces like countertops and doorknobs. How long it survives depends on the material the surface is made from.
The coronavirus responsible for the disease COVID-19 can remain intact on surfaces for anywhere up to 72 hours, according to a study conducted by US researchers.

The precise figure depends heavily on the type of surface infected droplets land on, and might also rely on the density of virus particles in the spray, and other environmental conditions - such as temperature and sunlight.

patterns: Is there a cure for covid19
Is there a treatment for covid19
Is there a medicine for covid19
Is there a cure for coronavirus
Is there a treatment for coronavirus
responses: While some western, traditional or home remedies may provide comfort and alleviate symptoms of COVID-19, there is no evidence that current medicine can prevent or cure the disease. WHO does not recommend self-medication with any medicines, including antibiotics, as a prevention or cure for COVID-19. However, there are several ongoing clinical trials that include both western and traditional medicines. WHO will continue to provide updated information as soon as clinical findings are available.

There is no specific treatment for disease caused by a novel coronavirus. However, many of the symptoms can be treated and therefore treatment based on the patient’s clinical condition. Moreover, supportive care for infected persons can be highly effective.

patterns: Antibiotics as a cure for coronavirus
Antibiotics as a cure for covid19
Antibiotics as a treatment for coronavirus
Antibiotics as a treatment for covid19
responses: Antibiotics do not work against viruses, they only work on bacterial infections. COVID-19 is caused by a virus, so antibiotics do not work.
Antibiotics should not be used as a means of prevention or treatment of COVID-19. They should only be used as directed by a physician to treat a bacterial infection.

patterns: Is there a vaccine for covid19
Is there a vaccine for coronavirus
Is there a vaccine for the virus
Where can i get any vaccine
Where can i get available vaccines
responses: To date, there is no vaccine and no specific antiviral medicine to prevent or treat COVID-2019. However, those affected should receive care to relieve symptoms.It will take months to develop a vaccine, although human trials have started at some places for it's development.

patterns: Can i get infected through animals
Can other animals transmit the virus
responses: Possible animal sources of COVID-19 have not yet been confirmed. To protect yourself, such as when visiting live animal markets, avoid direct contact with animals and surfaces in contact with animals. Ensure good food safety practices at all times.

responses: There is a possibility for some animals to become infected through close contact with infected humans. Further evidence is needed to understand if animals and pets can spread the disease. Based on current evidence, human to human transmission remains the main driver.

responses: Yes. The likelihood of an infected person contaminating commercial goods is low and the risk of catching the virus that causes COVID-19 from a package that has been moved, travelled, and exposed to different conditions and temperature is also low.

responses: Don't be stressed my friend, illness due to covid-19 corona is generally mild, the mortality rate is just about 4%, so #stayhomestaysafe and be safe. However, it can cause serious illness: about 1 in every 5 people who catch it need hospital care. It is therefore quite normal for people to worry about how the COVID-19 outbreak will affect them and their loved ones.

patterns: Can covid-19 be spread through coins and banknotes
Can the virus spread through money
Can it spread to coins and banknotes
Can the virus attach itself to money
Can i be infected by using infected coins or banknotes
responses: There is currently no evidence to confirm or disprove that COVID-19 virus can be transmitted through coins or banknotes. However, respiratory droplets expelled from an infected person can contaminate and persist on surfaces. Wash your hands regularly and thoroughly after touching any frequently-touched surface or object, including coins or banknotes. Avoid touching your eyes, mouth and nose, if your hands are not cleaned.

patterns: Should i wear mask to protect myself
Should i wear mask for the virus
Is it a must to wear a mask during the pandemic
Should i use mask to fight the virus
Can i use mask when im going out
Is it mandatory to use mask
responses: Only wear a mask if you are ill with COVID-19 symptoms (especially coughing) or looking after someone who may have COVID-19. Disposable face masks can only be used once. If you are not ill or looking after someone who is ill then you are wasting a mask. There is a world-wide shortage of masks, so WHO urges people to use masks wisely.

patterns: Is it safe to use alcohol to disinfect surfaces
Is it safe to use bleach to disinfect surfaces?

How to disinfect my whole body
How to disinfect your body properly?
responses: One of the most effective ways not to carry the virus is to wash your hands frequently with water and soap for at least 20seconds or take a shower especially when you are exposed from the outside, but the virus can still cling to surfaces you carry with you into your sanctuary. The surfaces or groceries can be disinfected with the use of a bleach mixture, to prepare a bleach mixture, 5 tablespoon bleach per gallon of water or 4 tablespoons bleach per quart of water and always use disposable gloves when disinfecting.

patterns: Is there a vitamins to prevent COVID

Should I start taking vitamins to prevent Coronavirus
responses: No supplement including vitamin C can prevent or treat Covid-19, even diet or other lifestyle modification other than physical distancing and proper hygiene can protect you from COVID-19
Vitamins can only boost your immunity, but no vitamins or supplement can prevent or cure COVID-19.

patterns: Is there asymptomatic transmission of the coronavirus disease
What if I am asymptomatic for the Coronavirus
How to know if I am infected but I am asymptomatic
responses: A disease is considered asymptomatic if a patient is a carrier for a disease or infection but experiences no symptoms. The risk of catching COVID-19 from someone with no symptoms at all is very low. Patient tests positive and has zero symptoms for the entire course of the disease. However, there are many cases where people are 'pre-symptomatic', where they have no symptoms at the time when they test positive but go on to develop symptoms later.

How is SARS related to covid19
responses:
The virus that causes COVID-19 and the one that caused the outbreak of Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS) in 2003 are related to each other genetically, but the diseases they cause are quite different.
SARS was more deadly but much less infectious than COVID-19. There have been no outbreaks of SARS anywhere in the world since 2003.

What do you mean by PUM?
How to be considered as PUM?
responses: Persons under monitoring(PUM) are persons who have travel history or had exposure to those with confirmed Covid but have no signs and symptoms, they are asked to be home quarantined for 14 days and wear a mask.
Asymptomatic patients with appropriate exposure history should be quarantined for 14 days to monitor the development of symptoms.
A person is considered as PUI if they don't have any symptoms but have travel history or had a  close contact with a person that has confirmed COVID.

patterns: What do you mean by PUI?
How to be considered as PUI?
responses: When a person is declared as Patients Under Investigation, he or she is exhibiting the coronavirus symptoms, has traveled in the past 14 days to areas with issued travel restriction, and has a history of exposure to COVID-19.

All forms of public transportation are suspended to battle the spread of the coronavirus. You can walk or ride a bicycle if you don't have a private vehicle.
Anything that falls under land, air, and sea travel are suspended.

patterns: How to protect myself from having Coronavirus?

responses: Regularly and thoroughly clean your hands with an alcohol-based hand rub or wash them with soap and water. Maintain at least 1 metre (3 feet) distance between yourself and anyone who is coughing or sneezing. Avoid touching eyes, nose and mouth.
Stay home if you feel unwell. If you have a fever, cough and difficulty breathing, seek medical attention and call in advance. Follow the directions of your local health authority.

patterns: Can I die from having COVID19?
Can people die from having COVID19?
Am I going to die if I have COVID19?
responses: COVID-19 could be fatal, but this happens rarely. According to WHO, 82% of infected patients will have mild presentations, 15% will have severe manifestations, and only 3% will be critical. As mentioned before, older people, people with compromised immune systems, and people with pre-existing medical conditions, such as diabetes and heart disease, are more prone to fall severely ill with the virus. Around 2% of people infected with the disease have died.

patterns: What is the difference between the PUI and PUM?

How to differ PUI from PUM?

responses: The difference between the PUI and PUM is that PUIs require hospital admission whereas PUMs only need to self-quarantine for 14 days.

Persons under monitoring(PUM) are persons who have travel history or had exposure to those with confirmed Covid but have no signs and symptoms, they are asked to be home quarantined for 14 days and wear a mask. While a person is considered as PUI if they have symptoms like fever, shortness of breath, diarrhea or dry cough.
